user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_BeginTest:
```c
void UtAssert_BeginTest(const char *SegmentName)
{
    uint32 TestSegmentCount;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    memset(&UT_SegmentCounters, 0, sizeof(UT_SegmentCounters));
    strncpy(CurrentSegment, SegmentName, sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1);
    CurrentSegment[sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1] = 0;
    TestSegmentCount                           = 1 + UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    UT_BSP_StartTestSegment(TestSegmentCount, SegmentName);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtAssert_BeginTest:
void UT_BSP_Lock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();
}
...
void UT_BSP_Unlock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();
}
...
void UT_BSP_StartTestSegment(uint32 SegmentNumber, const char *SegmentName)
{
    char ReportBuffer[128];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer), "%02u %s", (unsigned int)SegmentNumber, SegmentName);
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN, ReportBuffer);
}
...
UtAssert_TestCounter_t UT_SegmentCounters = {0}
...
UtAssert_TestCounter_t UT_TotalCounters   = {0}
...
static char            CurrentSegment[64]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function and related symbols for compiler-specific or nonstandard language extensions (e.g. keywords or constructs explicitly documented as extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, __inline__ (compiler-specific forms), __builtin_*, typeof (gcc extension), named sections, pragma with compiler-specific arguments, inline assembly, or other vendor-specific tokens). None are present. The code uses standard C constructs: function calls, local variable declaration, memset/strncpy/snprintf (standard library functions), a plain cast (unsigned int), static array definition, and brace initialization for globals. The identifier uint32 appears to be a typedef name (not a compiler extension token). Wrappers like UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock simply call implementation functions and do not use extension syntax. Therefore there are no code fragments to report for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (no explicit compiler language extensions found).
